Apollo_11.description: Apollo 11 achieved humanity’s first crewed landing on the Moon, marking the beginning of human lunar exploration.

sites.name: Mare Tranquillitatis
sites.description: The Sea of Tranquility is a basaltic plain chosen for its flat terrain and visibility. It was the landing site of Apollo 11 on July 20, 1969.
sites.importance: Site of the first human lunar landing.

sites.name: Mount Marilyn
sites.description: A small lunar mountain used as a visual landmark by Apollo 11 astronauts during descent.
sites.importance: Helped the Apollo 11 crew navigate visually during approach.

sites.name: Statio Tranquillitatis
sites.description: Also known as 'Tranquility Base', it is the precise site where the Lunar Module Eagle landed.
sites.importance: Historic site of the first human step on another world.

sites.name: West Crater
sites.description: A small crater located just east of the Apollo 11 landing site.
sites.importance: Served as a major visual reference during final descent.

Apollo_14.description: Apollo 14 returned to the Moon to complete scientific objectives canceled by Apollo 13, focusing on the Fra Mauro formation.

sites.name: Fra Mauro
sites.description: An elevated hilly region formed by ejecta from the Imbrium impact basin.
sites.importance: Landing site of Apollo 14; samples provided insight into the Moon’s impact history.

sites.name: Fra Mauro A
sites.description: A smaller satellite crater near the main Fra Mauro formation.
sites.importance: Part of the Fra Mauro highlands, offering diverse rock samples.

sites.name: Fra Mauro B
sites.description: Another minor crater in the Fra Mauro area.
sites.importance: Associated with the landing region of Apollo 14.

sites.name: Fra Mauro C
sites.description: One of several small craters used for geological study during Apollo 14.
sites.importance: Represents ejecta distribution from the Imbrium impact.

sites.name: Fra Mauro J
sites.description: A small crater located within the Fra Mauro formation.
sites.importance: Used for crater-count dating in Apollo 14 imagery.

sites.name: Fra Mauro Z
sites.description: Peripheral crater marking the boundary of the Fra Mauro region.
sites.importance: Identified in post-mission mapping of Apollo 14.

sites.name: Mare Imbrium
sites.description: The Sea of Rains, one of the Moon’s largest impact basins.
sites.importance: Source of the Fra Mauro ejecta studied during Apollo 14.

Apollo_15.description: Apollo 15 was the first 'J-mission', emphasizing scientific exploration and extended surface operations.

sites.name: Mons Hadley
sites.description: A large mountain at the eastern edge of Mare Imbrium.
sites.importance: Explored by Apollo 15 astronauts; provided anorthosite samples from the lunar crust.

sites.name: Mons Hadley Delta
sites.description: A smaller mountain adjacent to Mons Hadley.
sites.importance: Climbed partially by Apollo 15 crew during surface traverses.

sites.name: Rima Hadley
sites.description: A sinuous rille extending south of Mons Hadley.
sites.importance: Studied as a volcanic channel; sampled by Apollo 15.

sites.name: Terrace
sites.description: A sloped geological formation near Hadley Rille.
sites.importance: Provided insight into layering of lunar basalt flows.

Apollo_16.description: Apollo 16 focused on the Descartes Highlands to determine the origin of lunar highland materials.

sites.name: Descartes
sites.description: A small crater giving its name to the landing region.
sites.importance: Apollo 16 landed in the Descartes Highlands to test volcanic vs. impact origin theories.

sites.name: Plum
sites.description: A boulder and small crater near the Apollo 16 landing site.
sites.importance: Famous for being photographed with astronaut John Young; offered pristine breccia samples.

sites.name: Smoky Mountains
sites.description: Lunar highland ridge northwest of the landing area.
sites.importance: Geological background for sampling impact-melt rocks and ancient highland material.

Apollo_17.description: Apollo 17, the final Apollo mission, combined mountainous and mare terrains at the Taurus-Littrow Valley.

sites.name: Bear Mountain
sites.description: A ridge north of the Apollo 17 landing area.
sites.importance: Used as a visual landmark during landing and traverse planning.

sites.name: Littrow
sites.description: A crater and nearby rilles in the Taurus region.
sites.importance: Central to the Apollo 17 geology traverses.

sites.name: Montes Taurus
sites.description: Mountain range bordering Mare Serenitatis and the Taurus-Littrow Valley.
sites.importance: Surrounds the Apollo 17 landing site; provided highland rock samples.

sites.name: Rimae Littrow
sites.description: A system of rilles near the Littrow crater.
sites.importance: Studied for evidence of tectonic and volcanic activity.

sites.name: Shakespeare
sites.description: A small crater within the Taurus-Littrow region.
sites.importance: Used as a secondary geological reference during Apollo 17.

sites.name: Taurus Littrow Valley
sites.description: The Apollo 17 landing site located between the Taurus Mountains and the Littrow crater complex.
sites.importance: Final human landing on the Moon; provided orange volcanic glass samples.
